turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Could you tell us the --

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: I think the fact is that there are not very many of these.
When it's made clear to him that the law requires that he give up his own absolute right to the close that door on anyone.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think its criminal federally and the claim (Inaudible) the reasons before they're made, just duly do this?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: No, I don't think that's it Your Honor.
I think the basic reason is that people are reasonable.
They understand that people had lived down the hall or depended on their conditions.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is that the really a (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it's going to --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If people are going to let the inspectors (Inaudible) --

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: No, I -- the fact is that we found about 15% in San Francisco in fire inspections who didn't let inspectors in voluntarily.
When the Court announces that it is our constitutional right which it is not now, --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But yes (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: -- the Court announces that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- the Court also said, however, maybe your constitutional right to require a warrant but would the -- inspector can get the warrant, and what would it be to such a (Inaudible).
I would think it would be (Inaudible) they will get a warrant.
They may -- if they demand that he do it just to prove that he is who he is?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Well, no.

Now, that wouldn't be of any particular proof Mr. Justice White but it seems to me that this is into an area of legislature decisions as to what would be the best course of action and if -- as to what may happen and what we're concern with is the Constitution here?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, let's deal with the question I asked you a little awhile ago that for a moment there's a woman in her home alone with her children and a man comes to her door and says, “I will come in and inspect your house.
I'm a Department House Inspector”.

And she just feels in view of the conditions in the community and what's happening to the great many other housewives in the community that she's afraid for both of her children and herself to let a person like -- get in and she said -- says to him, “I won't let you come in unless you have a search warrant to do -- perform this job”.
And what do you going to do with that woman now?
You're going to put her in jail?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I hope not Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: I hope not but she has no right --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But if you have a right to insist on this man coming in to her house and there are just thousands and thousands of women in that situation in our state, what do you going to do about it?
You're going to say, ”Well, a woman can say that she won't let a person in but a man can?”

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
First of all to my knowledge, there has never been a criminal prosecution, a conviction and sentence of anyone under this ordinance that it -- this doesn't work.
It doesn't work that way.
She has to be convinced that she has no right to search a warrant does not apply.
That's what this Court has held and someone has to explain it to her.

And that the people that live near have rights as well as she and every reasonable effort that she wants to make to make sure this is the right person, to make sure her husband is there, to make sure of any reasonable conditions that can be taken cared of Your Honor and I'm sure it is taken cared of.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You mean by repetitive business going back, --

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: If she could --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- back and back and back.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: She can say, “Come in in another week.”

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, why wouldn't it be much easier to let -- to have him get this authorization to make the inspection go and so on said lady, there is the -- here's the warrant that the judge issued and the -- its much easier than -- even in this case for the man who went back three times just to have him -- tell him no, I won't let you go in.
I'll admit that I live there but I won't let you go in my house.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Well, what -- Your Honor, what standards would the magistrate use under that circumstance as to whether or not he should issue a search warrant --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: What facts would he ask for?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I am -- for myself, I would suggest that if you have a health ordinance that calls for annual inspection for apartment houses and it's his duty to go to this apartment house.
And a man or woman won't let him in, all he has to do is go back and get a warrant to admit him.
And when he has that, he has the power of the law behind him, and if they don't obey that then we've got an entirely different situation.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: I think Your Honor --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I think that most people would do that -- would let people in anyway if there's no danger of any -- anything wrong happening.
And he's not going to change her character and make them all demand search warrants, do you think so?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Well, you'd never know for one thing any more of that search warrant were not a forgery than -- for the people whether that's suspicious.
But I think the basic thing is this, the people could provide for that procedure if they wish but they have not provided for that.
That what Your Honor has mentioned is not a search warrant, as I understand a search warrant at all.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No, it's an administrative warrant.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: It would be a different thing and the Fourth Amendment does not have anything to do with that.
I say that is the legislative decision.
Thank you.
